thread.title: Future of North East economy depends on 'best possible' Brexit outcome, report says

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Future of North East economy depends on 'best possible' Brexit outcome, report says
text:
Future of North East economy depends on 'best possible' Brexit outcome, report says North East LEP report calls for access to European export markets to be maintained Share Part of the Newcastle City Centre skyline, including Grey's Monument (centre) (Image: Newcastle Journal) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The future success of the North East economy depends on the Government negotiating “the best possible terms of access to other markets” in the Brexit process, a new report will today say. 
The North East Local Enterprise Partnership is unveiling its first annual Our Economy report, saying that more than two-thirds of new jobs created in the North East should be highly skilled. 
The LEP’s Our Economy report highlights recent successes which have seen more than 55,000 new jobs created in the region between 2014 and 2017, more than half of the 100,000 target set by the LEP. Of those, 73% were classed as “better jobs”, meaning they were either at managerial level or above or in professional occupations. 
The report also highlights the region’s exporting record, which saw £12.7bn of goods exported in 2016/17, with the EU accounting for 59% of all exports - a higher rate than the rest of England. 
Discussing plans to maintain and strengthen the region’s international trade ties, the report says: “The North East LEP will work with its partners to deliver these objectives. 
“However, the success of these measures will also rely on the UK having strong relationships and appropriate treaties in place with other nations. 
“As the UK Government goes through the process of leaving the EU, it is critically important for the North East’s businesses and residents that they negotiate the best possible terms of access to other markets for the UK.” Read More Durham's Crafter's Companion forges partnership with UK art company 
The LEP report comes less than a month after a leaked Government impact report on Brexit revealed that the North East would be worst affected by leaving the EU, regardless of whatever deal was negotiated by the Government. 
Last week it was also warned that the UK automotive industry could be devastated by a no-deal Brexit, with the North East again likely to be among the hardest hit. Read More Gateshead firm wins contract to select Great North Run runners 
The LEP report revealed that machinery and transport accounted for 57% of exports in goods from the North East, followed by pharmaceuticals and manufactured goods. Between them, the three categories accounted for 90% of all exported goods from the region, with the LEP saying that “the region is heavily dependent on a small number of commodities for its exports”. 
The report outlines how the employment between the North East and the rest of England has narrowed by 28% since 2014, but the region had the lowest spending on R&D in England, and below average skill levels. Like us on Facebook
